# Mescalero

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the Native American tribe. For other uses, see
[Mescalero (disambiguation)](/wiki/Mescalero_\(disambiguation\) "Mescalero
\(disambiguation\)").

Mescalero Apache [![Mescalero Apache Tribal Offices Community Center New
Mexico.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Mescalero_Apache_Tribal_Offices_Community_Center_New_Mexico.jpg/300px-
Mescalero_Apache_Tribal_Offices_Community_Center_New_Mexico.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mescalero_Apache_Tribal_Offices_Community_Center_New_Mexico.jpg)
Mescalero Apache Tribal Administrative Offices and Community Center in
[Mescalero, New Mexico](/wiki/Mescalero,_New_Mexico "Mescalero, New Mexico")

Total population  
5,130

[Mescalero](/wiki/Mescalero-Chiricahua_language "Mescalero-Chiricahua
language"), [English](/wiki/English_language "English language"),

**Mescalero** or **Mescalero Apache** is an [Apache](/wiki/Apache "Apache")
tribe of [Southern Athabaskan](/wiki/Southern_Athabaskan_languages "Southern
Athabaskan languages") [Native
Americans](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native Americans in
the United States"). The tribe is federally recognized as the **Mescalero
Apache Tribe of the Mescalero Apache Reservation,** located in south central
[New Mexico](/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico").

In the nineteenth century, the Mescalero opened their reservation to other
[Apache](/wiki/Apache "Apache") bands, such as the [Mimbreno](/wiki/Mimbreno
"Mimbreno") and the [Chiricahua](/wiki/Chiricahua "Chiricahua"), many of whom
had been imprisoned in Florida. The [Lipan Apache](/wiki/Lipan_Apache_people
"Lipan Apache people") also joined the reservation. Their descendants are
enrolled in the Mescalero Apache Tribe.

## Reservation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mescalero&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Reservation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Mescalero_tipis.jpg/300px-
Mescalero_tipis.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mescalero_tipis.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mescalero_tipis.jpg "Enlarge")

Two Mescalero women, with [tipis](/wiki/Tipi "Tipi") and
[ramada](/wiki/Ramada_\(shelter\) "Ramada \(shelter\)") (to the left).

Originally established on May 27, 1873,[1] by Executive Order of President
[Ulysses S. Grant](/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant "Ulysses S. Grant"), the reservation
was first located near [Fort Stanton](/wiki/Fort_Stanton "Fort Stanton"). The
present reservation was established in 1883. It has a land area of 1,862.463
km² (719.101 sq mi), almost entirely in [Otero
County](/wiki/Otero_County,_New_Mexico "Otero County, New Mexico"). The
463,000-acre reservation lies on the eastern flank of the [Sacramento
Mountains](/wiki/Sacramento_Mountains "Sacramento Mountains") and borders the
[Lincoln National Forest](/wiki/Lincoln_National_Forest "Lincoln National
Forest"). A small unpopulated section is in [Lincoln
County](/wiki/Lincoln_County,_New_Mexico "Lincoln County, New Mexico") just
southwest of [Ruidoso](/wiki/Ruidoso,_New_Mexico "Ruidoso, New Mexico"). [U.S.
Route 70](/wiki/U.S._Route_70_in_New_Mexico "U.S. Route 70 in New Mexico") is
the major highway through the reservation.

The tribe has an economy based largely on ranching and tourism. The mountains
and foothills are forested with pines; resource and commercial development is
managed carefully by the Mescalero Apache Tribal Council. The Mescalero Apache
developed a cultural center near the tribal headquarters on U.S. Route 70 in
the reservation's largest community of [Mescalero](/wiki/Mescalero,_New_Mexico
"Mescalero, New Mexico"). On display are tribal artifacts and important
historical information. The tribe also operates another, larger museum on the
western flank of the [Sacramento Mountains](/wiki/Sacramento_Mountains
"Sacramento Mountains") in Dog Canyon, south of
[Alamogordo](/wiki/Alamogordo,_New_Mexico "Alamogordo, New Mexico").

The tribe developed and owns the Inn of the Mountain Gods Resort and Casino
("IMG") within Lincoln National Forest. As part of the IMG operation, the
tribe also owns and manages Ski Apache under contract as a concession with the
US Forest Service. It is the southernmost major ski area in North America. In
January 2012, Ski Apache celebrated its 50th anniversary.

The [ski area](/wiki/Ski_area "Ski area") is situated adjacent to the massive
peak of [Sierra Blanca](/wiki/Sierra_Blanca_\(New_Mexico\) "Sierra Blanca
\(New Mexico\)") a 12,003-foot (3,659 m) mountain.[2] It is the southernmost
alpine peak in the Continental [United States](/wiki/United_States "United
States") and is part of the [Sacramento Mountains](/wiki/Sacramento_Mountains
"Sacramento Mountains"). Using the EPA's Level III Ecoregion System, derived
from Omernik, this mountain is included in the "Arizona/New Mexico Mountains,"
which is south of the "Southern Rocky Mountains" of northern New Mexico.[3]
[Sierra Blanca](/wiki/Sierra_Blanca_\(New_Mexico\) "Sierra Blanca \(New
Mexico\)") peak, located on the reservation, is [sacred](/wiki/Sacred
"Sacred") ground for the Mescalero Apache Tribe. They do not allow access
without a permit.

## Tribal government[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mescalero&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Tribal government")]

The Mescalero Apache Tribe holds elections for the office of president every
two years. The eight Tribal Council members also are elected for two years.
Election for the Council is held every year, when one half of the members are
up for reelection. The reservation had a population of 3,156 according to the
[2000 census](/wiki/United_States_Census,_2000 "United States Census, 2000").

In 1959, the tribe elected [Virginia Klinekole](/wiki/Virginia_Klinekole
"Virginia Klinekole") as its first woman president.[4] She later was elected
to the Tribal Council, serving on it until 1986.[5] The tribe repeatedly re-
elected [Wendell Chino](/wiki/Wendell_Chino "Wendell Chino") as president; he
served a total of 43 years, until his death on November 4, 1998.

Soon after Chino's death, the late [Sara Misquez](/wiki/Sara_Misquez "Sara
Misquez") was elected as president. Chino's son, Mark Chino, also has been
elected and served as president.

New officers have served in the 21st century. On January 11, 2008 [Carleton
Naiche-Palmer](/wiki/Carleton_Naiche-Palmer "Carleton Naiche-Palmer") was
sworn in as the new president of the Mescalero Apache tribe.[6] From 2014 to
2018, Danny Breuninger was President of the Mescalero Apache Tribe. Currently
serving in the Office of President is Arthur "Butch" Blazer. Gabe Aguilar has
been Vice President of the Mescalero Apache Tribe since 2014.

## Culture and
language[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mescalero&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Culture and language")]

[![\[icon\]](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg) |  **This section needs expansion** with: section. You can help by [adding to it](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mescalero&action=edit&section=). _(October 2010)_  
---|---  
  
The [Mescalero language](/wiki/Mescalero_language "Mescalero language") is a
[Southern Athabaskan language](/wiki/Southern_Athabaskan_languages "Southern
Athabaskan languages") which is a subfamily of the
[Athabaskan](/wiki/Athabaskan_languages "Athabaskan languages") and
[Dené–Yeniseian](/wiki/Den%C3%A9%E2%80%93Yeniseian_languages "Dené–Yeniseian
languages") families. Mescalero is part of the southwestern branch of this
subfamily; it is very closely related to [Chiricahua](/wiki/Chiricahua
"Chiricahua"), and more distantly related to [Western
Apache](/wiki/Western_Apache "Western Apache"). These are considered the three
dialects of Apachean. Although Navajo is a related Southern Athabaskan
language, its language and culture are considered distinct from those of the
Apache.

The Mescalero Apache were primarily a nomadic mountain people. They traveled
east on the arid plains to hunt the buffalo and south into the desert for
gathering [Mescal Agave](/wiki/Mescal_Agave "Mescal Agave"). Spanish colonists
associated them with this plant and named them Mescalero Apache. The Mescalero
Apache, along with the other Apache groups, lived by traditional hunting and
gathering. If conditions were poor, they raided other tribes, and Spanish,
Mexican and American settlers to survive.

## Origin of name[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mescalero&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Origin of name")]

The Mescalero's autonym, or name for themselves, is _**Shis-Inday**_ ("People
of the Mountain Forests") or _**Mashgalénde**_ (“People close to the
mountains”).[7] The [Navajo](/wiki/Navajo_people "Navajo people"), another
[Athabascan](/wiki/Athabaskan_languages "Athabaskan languages")-speaking
tribe, call the Mescalero _**Naashgalí Dineʼé.**_[8] Like other Apache peoples
they often identify simply as _**Inday / Indee**_ ("The People"). Neighboring
Apache bands called the Mescalero _**Nadahéndé**_ ("People of the Mescal"),
because the mescal agave (_[Agave parryi](/wiki/Agave_parryi "Agave parryi")_)
was a staple [food source](/wiki/Agave#Uses "Agave") for them. In times of
need and hunger, they depended on stored mescal for survival. Since 1550
Spanish colonists referred to them as the _Mescalero._

Mescalero Apache bands were often referred to by European colonists and
settlers by different names, some related to their geographic territory. They
were recorded in documents by a wide number of names: _Apaches de Cuartelejo,
Apaches del Río Grande, Apachi, Faraones, Mezcaleros, Natage (more correctly,
one of the Lipan Apache subdivisions, along with the Nahizan), Natahene,
Querechos, Teyas, Tularosa Apaches, and Vaqueros._ They were also
distinguished as _Sierra Blanca Apaches, Sacramento Mountains Apaches,
Guadalupe Mountains Apaches, Limpia Mountains Apaches._ according to their
homelands in northern or southern Mescalero territory.

## Tribal territory[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mescalero&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Tribal territory")]

Originally the different Mescalero bands and local groups ranged in an area
between the [Rio Grande](/wiki/Rio_Grande "Rio Grande") in the west and the
eastern and southern edge of the [Llano Estacado](/wiki/Llano_Estacado "Llano
Estacado") and the southern [Texas Panhandle](/wiki/Texas_Panhandle "Texas
Panhandle") in Texas in the east; from present-day [Santa
Fe](/wiki/Santa_Fe,_New_Mexico "Santa Fe, New Mexico") in the northwest and
the [Texas Panhandle](/wiki/Texas_Panhandle "Texas Panhandle") in the
northeast, down to the [Big Bend](/wiki/Big_Bend_\(Texas\) "Big Bend
\(Texas\)") of Texas and what became the Mexican provinces of Chihuahua and
Coahuila to the south. The diverse landscape of this area has high mountains
up to 12,000 feet, as well as watered and sheltered valleys, surrounded by
arid semi-deserts and deserts, deep canyons and open plains. The Mescalero
Apache Reservation is located at [geographical
coordinates](/wiki/Geographical_coordinates "Geographical coordinates")
[33°10′42″N 105°36′44″W﻿ / ﻿33.17833°N 105.61222°W﻿ / 33.17833;
-105.61222](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Mescalero&params=33_10_42_N_105_36_44_W_scale:500000).

Since each band of Mescalero had the right to use the resources of deer and
plants of the neighboring groups, the different bands felt at home in any area
of their wide tribal territory. The Mescalero bands often ranged widely for
hunting, gathering, warring and raiding. They called their home **Indeislun
Nakah** ("people, forming a group, when they are there," "place where people
get together"). When many Mescalero bands were displaced by the enemy
[Comanche](/wiki/Comanche "Comanche") from the Southern Plains in northern and
central Texas between 1700–1750, they took refuge in the mountains of New
Mexico, western Texas, and Coahuila and Chihuahua in Mexico. Some southern
Mescalero bands, together with Lipan, lived in the [Bolsón de
Mapimí](/wiki/Bols%C3%B3n_de_Mapim%C3%AD "Bolsón de Mapimí"), moving between
the [Nazas River](/wiki/Nazas_River "Nazas River"), the [Conchos
River](/wiki/Conchos_River "Conchos River") and the [Rio
Grande](/wiki/Rio_Grande "Rio Grande") to the north.

## Bands[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mescalero&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Bands")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Mescalero%2C_Painted_boy.jpg/220px-
Mescalero%2C_Painted_boy.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mescalero,_Painted_boy.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mescalero,_Painted_boy.jpg "Enlarge")

Mescalero painted boy; photo entitled _[Long Walk of the
Navajo](/wiki/Long_Walk_of_the_Navajo "Long Walk of the Navajo")_. After being
defeated by United States military forces, most of the [Navajo](/wiki/Navajo
"Navajo") were marched over 350-mile (560 km) during the winter of 1864 and
incarcerated at [Bosque Redondo, New Mexico](/wiki/Bosque_Redondo,_New_Mexico
"Bosque Redondo, New Mexico") with the Mescalero Apache.

  * **Natahéndé / Nadahéndé** (Spanish rendering - translteration - as _Natages,_ pronounced Na-ta-hay, "Mescal People"; lived between [Rio Grande](/wiki/Rio_Grande "Rio Grande") and [Pecos River](/wiki/Pecos_River "Pecos River") in central [New Mexico](/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico"), with local groups traveling on the southern and western edge of the [Llano Estacado](/wiki/Llano_Estacado "Llano Estacado") onto the southern [Texas Panhandle](/wiki/Texas_Panhandle "Texas Panhandle"))
  * **Guhlkahéndé / Guułgahénde** (Spanish rendering as _Cuelcajenne_ , "People of the Plains"; lived east of the mountains and the Pecos River, on the High Plains from the Texas Panhandle to the Pecos Valley, between [Amarillo](/wiki/Amarillo,_TX "Amarillo, TX"), [Tucumcari](/wiki/Tucumcari,_NM "Tucumcari, NM"), [Lubbock](/wiki/Lubbock,_TX "Lubbock, TX") and the Llano Estacado, along the Sandia and Tijeras Mountains westward to [Santa Fe](/wiki/Santa_Fe,_NM "Santa Fe, NM"), from Nogal Canyon to the north to [Las Vegas](/wiki/Las_Vegas,_NM "Las Vegas, NM"), from the [Organ Mountains](/wiki/Organ_Mountains "Organ Mountains") eastwards to [El Paso](/wiki/El_Paso,_TX "El Paso, TX"). In Oklahoma (Indian Territory) they developed kinship ties by marriage with the [Comanche](/wiki/Comanche "Comanche").)
  * **Dzithinahndé** / **Tsilnihéndé** (Spanish rendering as _Chilpaines_ , "Mountain Ridge Band People", lived in the mountains west and south of the Pecos River, extending in northern [Chihuahua](/wiki/Chihuahua_\(state\) "Chihuahua \(state\)") and [Coahuila](/wiki/Coahuila "Coahuila") of present-day Mexico.)
  * **Ch 'laandé** / **Tslahahéndé** ("Antelope Band People"; lived west of the Pecos west to the Rio Grande in the mountains of central and south New Mexico and the [Tularosa Basin](/wiki/Tularosa_Basin "Tularosa Basin").)
  * **Nit 'ahéndé / Niit’ahénde** ("People Who Live Against the Mountains", "Earth Crevine (Deer) People"; lived in the [Sacramento Mountains](/wiki/Sacramento_Mountains "Sacramento Mountains") in New Mexico and the [Guadalupe Mountains](/wiki/Guadalupe_Mountains "Guadalupe Mountains") in western Texas.)
  * **Tsehitcihéndé** ("People of Hook Nose", several bands, who lived in the Guadalupe Mountains, the adjacent Plains of Texas and in northern Coahuila and Chihuahua of Mexico.)
  * **Tsebekinéndé** ("Rock House People", often called by Spanish and Americans _Aguas Nuevas_ or _Norteños,_ have been based around the [Nuevo Casas Grandes](/wiki/Nuevo_Casas_Grandes "Nuevo Casas Grandes") in Chihuahua, migrating north toward the Sacramento Mountains and south to Agua Nueva 60 miles north of [Chihuahua City](/wiki/Chihuahua,_Chihuahua "Chihuahua, Chihuahua"), also on both sides of the Rio Grande between El Paso and [Ojinaga, Chihuahua](/wiki/Ojinaga,_Chihuahua "Ojinaga, Chihuahua"); some local groups lived in the Guadalupe and Limpia mountains)
  * **Tahuundé / Tá 'huú'ndé** ("Mountains Extending into the River People", lived on both sides of the Pecos River in southern New Mexico and into southwestern Texas)
  * **Tuintsundé / Túntsande** ("Big Water People", once the _Tú sis Ndé_ band of the [Lipan Apache](/wiki/Lipan_Apache_people "Lipan Apache people"), who lived in south central Texas and in northern Coahuila, camping together with several bands of the Mescalero on the Plains for hunting and raiding; they merged with the Mescalero, forming a Mescalero band)
  * **Tuetinini / Tú’é’dinénde** ("No Water People", "Tough People of the Desert", once the _Tú é diné Ndé_ band of the Lipan Apache, who had territory in northern Coahuila and Chihuahua; they eventually merged with some southern Mescalero bands)

The _Natahéndé_ had had a considerable influence on the decision-making of
some bands of the Western Lipan in the 18th century, especially on the _Tindi
Ndé_ , _Tcha shka-ózhäye_ , _Tú é diné Ndé_ and _Tú sis Ndé_. To fight their
common enemy, the Comanche, and to protect the northeastern and eastern border
of the [Apacheria](/wiki/Apacheria "Apacheria") against the
[Comancheria](/wiki/Comancheria "Comancheria"), the Mescalero (_Natahéndé_ and
_Guhlkahéndé_) on the Plains joined forces with their Lipan kin (_Cuelcahen
Ndé_ , _Te 'l kóndahä_, _Ndáwe qóhä_ and _Shá i`a Nde_) to the east and south
of them.

In August 1912, by an act of the U.S. Congress, the surviving members of the
[Chiricahua](/wiki/Chiricahua "Chiricahua") tribe were released from their
prisoner-of-war status. They were given the choice to remain at [Fort
Sill](/wiki/Fort_Sill "Fort Sill"), Oklahoma, where they had been imprisoned
since ?, or to relocate to the Mescalero Apache reservation. One hundred and
eighty-three elected to go to New Mexico, while seventy-eight remained in
Oklahoma.[9] Their descendants still reside in both places.

## Notable Mescalero[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mescalero&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Notable Mescalero")]

### Historical chiefs and
headmen[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mescalero&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Historical chiefs and headmen")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Gorgonia%2C_Mescalero_medicine_man.jpg/170px-
Gorgonia%2C_Mescalero_medicine_man.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gorgonia,_Mescalero_medicine_man.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gorgonia,_Mescalero_medicine_man.jpg "Enlarge")

_Gorgonia_ , Sierrablanca Mescalero medicine man

[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

  * [Gorgonio](/w/index.php?title=Gorgonio_\(medicine_man\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Gorgonio \(medicine man\) \(page does not exist\)"), northern Mescalero medicine-man, aide to old Barranquito and, later, to Santana.
  * [Gómez](/w/index.php?title=G%C3%B3mez_\(chief\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Gómez \(chief\) \(page does not exist\)"), southern Mescalero chief who led a large band of five local groups with about 400 warriors. His band lived in the Big Bend Country and the Trans-Pecos on both sides of the Rio Grande; his stronghold was in the [Limpia Mountains](/wiki/Limpia_Mountains "Limpia Mountains"), later named [Davis Mountains](/wiki/Davis_Mountains "Davis Mountains"). When Governor Trias offered 1,000 pesos for his scalp, Gómez offered an equal amount for any Mexican or American scalp. His _segundos_ \- or war chiefs - were Cigarito, Chinonero, Simón Porode, and Simón Manuel.[10]
    * Cigarito, leader of a local group in the Limpia also known as Davis Mountains and in the lowlands of the Trans-Pecos; _segundo_ and war chief of southern Mescalero Chief Gómez, 1840s - 1860s
    * Chinonero, leader of a local group in the Limpia also known as Davis Mountains and in the lowlands of the Trans-Pecos; _segundo_ and war chief of southern Mescalero chief Gómez, 1840s - 1860s)
    * Simón Porode, leader of a local group in West-Texas; _segundo_ and war chief of southern Mescalero chief Gómez. In 1850 he and Simón Manuel contacted the garrison at San Elizario to sue for peace, but were likely overruled by Gómez, 1840s - 1860s.
    * Simón Manuel, leader of a local group in West-Texas; _segundo_ and war chief of southern Mescalero chief Gómez. In 1850 he and leader Simón Porode contacted the garrison at San Elizario to sue for peace, but were likely overruled by Gómez, 1840s - 1860s)
  * [Marco](/w/index.php?title=Marco_\(chief\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Marco \(chief\) \(page does not exist\)") (also known as _Marcus_) southern Mescalero chief who led a band of about 600 people, including about 200 warriors - presumably _Tsehitcihéndé_ or _Niit’ahénde._ They lived in the Big Bend Country, ranged on both sides of the Rio Grande from the [Guadalupe Mountains](/wiki/Guadalupe_Mountains "Guadalupe Mountains") toward east of the Limpia Mountains also known as Davis Mountains onto the edge of the Southern Plains. He was reported to have led frequent raids and attacks of parties on the San Antonio road and in the settlement near El Paso. He wished to join the Sierra Blanca Mescalero band, but their request was refused, because they were considered a Texas Mescalero band; active in the 1840s - 1860s.
  * [Espejo](/w/index.php?title=Espejo_\(chief\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Espejo \(chief\) \(page does not exist\)") (“looking-glass”), southern Mescalero chief led a large band, presumably _Tsebekinéndé,_ with several local groups under his _segundos_ (or war chiefs) Nicolás and Antonio. They ranged between Limpia Canyon, [Horsehead Crossing](/wiki/Horsehead_Crossing "Horsehead Crossing") on the Pecos and east of the Limpia also known as Davis Mountains onto the surrounding desert lowlands of the [Trans-Pecos](/wiki/Trans-Pecos "Trans-Pecos") in [West Texas](/wiki/West_Texas "West Texas"), from the 1840s - late 1860s. 
    * Nicolás, leader of a local group of the _Tsebekinéndé_ band in the Limpia also known as Davis Mountains and east onto the edge of the Southern Plains, _segundo_ and war chief of southern Mescalero chief Espejo, 1840s - 1860s.
    * Antonio, leader of a local group of the _Tsebekinéndé_ band in the Limpia also known as Davis Mountains and east onto the edge of the Southern Plains, _segundo_ and war chief of southern Mescalero chief Espejo, 1840s - 1860s.
  * [Mateo](/w/index.php?title=Mateo_\(chief\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Mateo \(chief\) \(page does not exist\)") leader of a local group of the _Tsebekinéndé_ (often called by Spanish and Americans _Aguas Nuevas_ or _Norteños_), stayed together with Verancia in the vicinity of Dog Canyon in the [Sacramento Mountains](/wiki/Sacramento_Mountains "Sacramento Mountains") and presumably followed the old ways of hunt and raid, since they were considered "troublesome.", 1840s - 1860s[11]
  * [Verancia](/w/index.php?title=Verancia_\(chief\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Verancia \(chief\) \(page does not exist\)"), said to be a son of Gomez, leader of a local group of the _Tsebekinéndé_ , stayed together with Mateo in the vicinity of Dog Canyon in the [Sacramento Mountains](/wiki/Sacramento_Mountains "Sacramento Mountains") and presumably followed the old ways of hunt and raid, since they were considered "troublesome.", 1840s - 1860s)
  * [Barranquito](/w/index.php?title=Barranquito_\(chief\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Barranquito \(chief\) \(page does not exist\)") (also known as _Palanquito_), most influential chief of the Sierra Blanca Mescalero band, which ranged between the [Sierra Blanca Mountains](/wiki/Sierra_Blanca_\(New_Mexico\) "Sierra Blanca \(New Mexico\)") east toward the Pecos River, probably the most important Mescalero chief in the early 1800s, when he died in 1857, his three sons and/or nephews Santana, Cadete and Roman succeeded him
  * [Santana](/w/index.php?title=Santana_\(chief\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Santana \(chief\) \(page does not exist\)") (also known as _Santa Ana_), ca. 1810 - †1876, son and successor of Barranquito, since about 1830' had been a local group leader of great authority of the Sierra Blanca Mescalero band, since the death of Barranquito Santana seem to have had the most influence within the northern Mescalero bands, but avoided the spotlight and was hardly known by the whites, in his later years he became the most steadfast friend of the whites, until his death of pneumonia or smallpox
  * [Cadete](/w/index.php?title=Cadete_\(chief\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Cadete \(chief\) \(page does not exist\)") (also known as _Cadette_ \- “Volunteer”, in Apache: _Gian-na-tah_ (“Always Ready”),[12] also known as _Zhee-es-not-son_ , _Zhee Ah Nat Tsa_), a son and successor of Barranquito. After Santana he was the most prominent and powerful chief of the Sierra Blanca Mescalero band, was more diplomatic than Santana and was a spokesman for the northern Mescalero bands. After the outbreak from Bosque Redondo on November 3, 1863, he had fled with his band toward the Staked Plains, trading stolen cattle and horses from Mexico directly or via the Comanchero to Comanche. He was murdered in 1872 while on a peace mission and returning from Tularosa.
  * [Roman Grande](/w/index.php?title=Roman_Grande_\(chief\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Roman Grande \(chief\) \(page does not exist\)"), a son and successor of Barranquito, serving as chief of a local group of the Sierra Blanca Mescalero band. Less important than Santana and Cadete, he followed the lead of his brother Santana; died during an [epidemic](/wiki/Epidemic "Epidemic") in 1885.
  * [Josecito](/w/index.php?title=Josecito&action=edit&redlink=1 "Josecito \(page does not exist\)") (also known as _José Cito_), after Barranquito and Santana, the most prominent leader of some local groups of the Sierra Blanca Mescalero band. In April 1852 he signed a treaty with Calhoun representing the US, together with the minor leader of another group of the Sierra Blanca Mescalero and Chacon, leader of the Jicarilla Apache.
  * [Nautzili](/w/index.php?title=Nautzili_\(chief\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Nautzili \(chief\) \(page does not exist\)") (also known as _Natzili_ , _Nautzile_ , _Nodzilla_ \- "buffalo"), chief of the _Guhlkahéndé_ and southern Lipan splinter groups living in northern Mexico, moved to reservation in 1876. In 1879 he had assumed leadership of most of the Mescalero reservation bands (including the Lipan) and persuaded many warriors not to join the Tchihende chief [Victorio](/wiki/Victorio "Victorio") in [Victorio's War](/wiki/Victorio%27s_War "Victorio's War").
  * [San Juan](/w/index.php?title=San_Juan_\(chief\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "San Juan \(chief\) \(page does not exist\)") (Chief of maybe the _Nit 'ahéndé_ or _Tsehitcihéndé_ band), his band ranged along the [Rio Bonito](/wiki/Rio_Bonito_\(New_Mexico\) "Rio Bonito \(New Mexico\)"), [Rio Hondo](/wiki/Rio_Hondo_\(Southern_New_Mexico\) "Rio Hondo \(Southern New Mexico\)") and in the [Capitan Mountains](/wiki/Capitan_Mountains "Capitan Mountains") with the Sacramento Mountains - the area where Fort Stanton was built -, had alliances with eastern Mescalero bands, Lipan Apache bands as well as some Comanche bands; after Santana and Cadete were gone, chief San Juan and Nautzili took over the leadership of the Mescaleros on the reservation, but, unlike Nautzili, San Juan left the reservation in spring 1880, after Caballero's outbreak, during "Victorio's war"; his son Peso would become the last Mescalero chief
  * [Caballero](/w/index.php?title=Caballero_\(chief\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Caballero \(chief\) \(page does not exist\)") (_Ca-bal-le-so_ , eventually to be identified with _[Kutbhalla](/w/index.php?title=Kutbhalla&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kutbhalla \(page does not exist\)")_ or _Kutu-hala_), war chief and later principal chief of the bands of the [Sacramento Mountains](/wiki/Sacramento_Mountains "Sacramento Mountains") during the decades 1860s and 1870s, likely married to a daughter of the Chihenne Chief [Mangas Coloradas](/wiki/Mangas_Coloradas "Mangas Coloradas"), close ally and long-time friend of the great Mimbreño chief [Victorio](/wiki/Victorio "Victorio") (and likely his brother-in-law as Mangas Coloradas' son-in-law); in March 1880 he left Tularosa and joined Victorio, fighting alongside with him their last battles, but, according to some reports, he was killed in a trouble between the chiefs before the Tres Castillos massacre on oct. 14 1880)
  * [Alsate](/wiki/Alsate "Alsate") (also known as _Arzate_ , _Arzatti_ , also known as Pedro Muzquiz, ca. *1820 - †1881/1882), last Chief of the Chisos Apaches (also _Chinati_ or _Rio Grande Apaches_ , a Mescalero band in the [Limpia Mountains](/wiki/Limpia_Mountains "Limpia Mountains") (also known as [Davis Mountains](/wiki/Davis_Mountains "Davis Mountains")), [Chisos Mountains](/wiki/Chisos_Mountains "Chisos Mountains") and [Chinati Mountains](/wiki/Chinati_Mountains "Chinati Mountains")[13] in the [Big Bend](/wiki/Big_Bend_\(Texas\) "Big Bend \(Texas\)") area, the [Sierra del Carmen](/wiki/Sierra_del_Carmen "Sierra del Carmen") of Coahuila and [Sierra Alamos](/w/index.php?title=Sierra_Alamos&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sierra Alamos \(page does not exist\)") in Chihuahua north of the [Bolsón de Mapimí](/wiki/Bols%C3%B3n_de_Mapim%C3%AD "Bolsón de Mapimí"),[14] born to a Mescalero woman and a member by blood of the influential Muzquiz family, captured with his band in 1878 at San Carlos de Chihuahua and deported to Mexico City to be jailed in "la Acordada", succeeded in escaping with his people in December 1879 and came back to the Big Bend; was caught again at San Carlos de Chihuahua in 1880 and executed together with his _segundos_ (or war chiefs) Colorado and Zorillo at [Ojinaga](/wiki/Ojinaga "Ojinaga"), opposite [Presidio del Norte](/wiki/Presidio,_Texas "Presidio, Texas"), Texas, his people were sold into slavery in Mexico, ca. 1860 - 1882)[15]
    * Colorado ("Red", likely "Avispa Colorada" "Red Wasp") leader of a local group of Chisos, or maybe Lipan, Apaches in the border region of Coahuila, Chihuahua and West-Texas, _segundo_ and war chief of the Chisos Mescalero chief Alsate, was caught and executed together with Alsate and Zorillo at Ojinaga, opposite Presidio del Norte, Texas, late 1860s - 1882
    * Zorillo (likely "Zorrillo" "Little Fox")) leader of a local group of Chisos Apaches in the border region of Coahuila, Chihuahua and West-Texas, _segundo_ and war chief of the Chisos Mescalero chief Alsate, was caught and executed together with Alsate and Colorado at Ojinaga, opposite Presidio del Norte, Texas, late 1860s - 1882
  * [Carnoviste](/w/index.php?title=Carnoviste_\(chief\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Carnoviste \(chief\) \(page does not exist\)"), hostile southern Mescalero chief, his band - presumably _Tsehitcihéndé_ or _Niit’ahénde_ \- lived in the Big Bend Country, ranged on both sides of the Rio Grande from the [Guadalupe Mountains](/wiki/Guadalupe_Mountains "Guadalupe Mountains") towards east of the Limpia Mountains also known as Davis Mountains onto the edge of the Southern Plains, was reported to have committed frequent "depredations" on the San Antonio road and to have kidnapped Hermann - soon adopted in the tribe - and Willie Lehmann near Fort Mason in May 1870; in 1874 he promoted a council of Mescalero, Mimbreño and Lipan Apache chiefs, and Victorio succeeded in persuading the council to send peace messengers to the Comanches and Kiowas; he was killed by a medicine man of his band in the spring 1876
  * [Peso](/w/index.php?title=Peso_\(chief\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Peso \(chief\) \(page does not exist\)"), ca. *1849 - †1929, was born in the [Guadalupe Mountains](/wiki/Guadalupe_Mountains "Guadalupe Mountains") near present-day [Carlsbad](/wiki/Carlsbad,_New_Mexico "Carlsbad, New Mexico") as son of chief San Juan and his wife Nagoo-nah-go, his band - maybe _Nit 'ahéndé_ or _Tsehitcihéndé_ \- joined Nautzili's band of Guhlkahéndé on the Southern Plains, from time to time he also joined the _Tu 'sis Nde_ band of Lipan Apaches of southeastern Texas and northeastern Mexico under Chief Magoosh, he was an expert tracker and served as Apache Scout in the campaigns against [Geronimo](/wiki/Geronimo "Geronimo"), in the late 1800s he, together with his brother Sin Miedo (Sans Peur, Without Fear) and Magoosh were the three primary leaders on the reservation - Magoosh for the Lipans at Elk Springs, Sin Miedo at Tule Canyon and Peso representing the Rinconada and the Three Rivers
  * [Sin Miedo](/w/index.php?title=Sin_Miedo\(chief\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sin Miedo\(chief\) \(page does not exist\)") (“Without Fear” = “[Sans Peur](/w/index.php?title=Sans_Peur_\(chief\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sans Peur \(chief\) \(page does not exist\)")”), brother of chief Peso and son of chief San Juan, his band - maybe _Nit 'ahéndé_ or _Tsehitcihéndé_ \- were close allies of the eastern Mescalero band named Guhlkahéndé on the Southern Plains and of the _Tu 'sis Nde_ band of Lipan Apaches of southeastern Texas and northeastern Mexico; together with his brothers Peso, Crook Neck, and leaders as Shanta Boy and Big Mouth he served as Apache Scout in the campaign against Geronimo, the war leader and shaman of the Bedonkohe band of the Ndendhe Apaches; he, together with his brother Peso and Magoosh were the three primary leaders on the reservation - Magoosh for the Lipans at Elk Springs, Peso representing the Rinconada and the Three Rivers, and Sin Miedo at Tule Canyon
  * [Muchacho Negro](/w/index.php?title=Muchacho_Negro&action=edit&redlink=1 "Muchacho Negro \(page does not exist\)") (“Black Boy”), local group leader of warriors, joined the Chihenne Chief Victorio, about 1860, died 1930.
